001// Copyright (c) FIRST and other WPILib contributors.
002// Open Source Software; you can modify and/or share it under the terms of
003// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.
004
005package edu.wpi.first.wpilibj;
006
007public class Timer {
008  /**
009   * Return the system clock time in seconds. Return the time from the FPGA hardware clock in
010   * seconds since the FPGA started.
011   *
012   * @return Robot running time in seconds.
013   */
014  @SuppressWarnings("AbbreviationAsWordInName")
015  public static double getFPGATimestamp() {
016    return RobotController.getFPGATime() / 1000000.0;
017  }
018
019  /**
020   * Return the approximate match time. The FMS does not send an official match time to the robots,
021   * but does send an approximate match time. The value will count down the time remaining in the
022   * current period (auto or teleop). Warning: This is not an official time (so it cannot be used to
023   * dispute ref calls or guarantee that a function will trigger before the match ends) The Practice
024   * Match function of the DS approximates the behavior seen on the field.
025   *
026   * @return Time remaining in current match period (auto or teleop) in seconds
027   */
028  public static double getMatchTime() {
029    return DriverStation.getMatchTime();
030  }
031
032  /**
033   * Pause the thread for a specified time. Pause the execution of the thread for a specified period
034   * of time given in seconds. Motors will continue to run at their last assigned values, and
035   * sensors will continue to update. Only the task containing the wait will pause until the wait
036   * time is expired.
037   *
038   * @param seconds Length of time to pause
039   */
040  public static void delay(final double seconds) {
041    try {
042      Thread.sleep((long) (seconds * 1e3));
043    } catch (final InterruptedException ex) {
044      Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
045    }
046  }
047
048  private double m_startTime;
049  private double m_accumulatedTime;
050  private boolean m_running;
051
052  /** Lock for synchronization. */
053  private final Object m_lock = new Object();
054
055  @SuppressWarnings("MissingJavadocMethod")
056  public Timer() {
057    reset();
058  }
059
060  private double getMsClock() {
061    return RobotController.getFPGATime() / 1000.0;
062  }
063
064  /**
065   * Get the current time from the timer. If the clock is running it is derived from the current
066   * system clock the start time stored in the timer class. If the clock is not running, then return
067   * the time when it was last stopped.
068   *
069   * @return Current time value for this timer in seconds
070   */
071  public double get() {
072    synchronized (m_lock) {
073      if (m_running) {
074        return m_accumulatedTime + (getMsClock() - m_startTime) / 1000.0;
075      } else {
076        return m_accumulatedTime;
077      }
078    }
079  }
080
081  /**
082   * Reset the timer by setting the time to 0. Make the timer startTime the current time so new
083   * requests will be relative now
084   */
085  public void reset() {
086    synchronized (m_lock) {
087      m_accumulatedTime = 0;
088      m_startTime = getMsClock();
089    }
090  }
091
092  /**
093   * Start the timer running. Just set the running flag to true indicating that all time requests
094   * should be relative to the system clock. Note that this method is a no-op if the timer is
095   * already running.
096   */
097  public void start() {
098    synchronized (m_lock) {
099      if (!m_running) {
100        m_startTime = getMsClock();
101        m_running = true;
102      }
103    }
104  }
105
106  /**
107   * Stop the timer. This computes the time as of now and clears the running flag, causing all
108   * subsequent time requests to be read from the accumulated time rather than looking at the system
109   * clock.
110   */
111  public void stop() {
112    synchronized (m_lock) {
113      m_accumulatedTime = get();
114      m_running = false;
115    }
116  }
117
118  /**
119   * Check if the period specified has passed.
120   *
121   * @param seconds The period to check.
122   * @return Whether the period has passed.
123   */
124  public boolean hasElapsed(double seconds) {
125    synchronized (m_lock) {
126      return get() > seconds;
127    }
128  }
129
130  /**
131   * Check if the period specified has passed and if it has, advance the start time by that period.
132   * This is useful to decide if it's time to do periodic work without drifting later by the time it
133   * took to get around to checking.
134   *
135   * @param period The period to check for (in seconds).
136   * @return Whether the period has passed.
137   * @deprecated Use advanceIfElapsed() instead.
138   */
139  @Deprecated(since = "2022", forRemoval = true)
140  public boolean hasPeriodPassed(double period) {
141    return advanceIfElapsed(period);
142  }
143
144  /**
145   * Check if the period specified has passed and if it has, advance the start time by that period.
146   * This is useful to decide if it's time to do periodic work without drifting later by the time it
147   * took to get around to checking.
148   *
149   * @param seconds The period to check.
150   * @return Whether the period has passed.
151   */
152  public boolean advanceIfElapsed(double seconds) {
153    synchronized (m_lock) {
154      if (get() > seconds) {
155        // Advance the start time by the period.
156        // Don't set it to the current time... we want to avoid drift.
157        m_startTime += seconds * 1000;
158        return true;
159      } else {
160        return false;
161      }
162    }
163  }
164}
